prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We apply for a bandwidth 1875 MHz, with spectral resolution 31.25 MHz (27.1 km/s), which is better than the final request resolution. However, the expected line may also be stronger, and we might be able to derive kinematic information from them. And other basebands could also potentially detect lines from other molecular transitions. So we would like to keep the resolution.

From previous studies (Weiss et al. 2013), we know the size of the galaxy is less than 5", and is unresolved. Our uniformly requested resolution 2" will match each other, and may have chance to resolve the spatial distribution.

Line peak fluxes and FWHM estimated from Omont et al. 2013. We assume that the fluxes of 12CO 3-2,4-3, and 5-4 are similar, adopting an averaged line ladder values of SMG (Carilli & Walter 2013). For the isotopologus we assume the line intensity ratios of 12CO/13CO is 20, which is the value found in Eyelash (Danielson et al. 2013). And we assume that 13CO has similar flux as C18O. An rms loise level of 0.4 mJy at a velocity bin of 100 km/s would ensure detections at 4-6 sigma at the peak channel. Since we are interested in the total velocity-integrated fluxes, the final S/N will be > 10- 15. So even C18O is weaker than 13CO, we should be able to safely detect them.

And other basebands could also potentially detect lines from other molecular transitions. So we would like to keep the resolution.

Line peak fluxes and FWHM estimated from Weiss et al. (2013). We assume that the fluxes of 12CO 3-2,4-3, and 5-4 are similar, adopting an averaged line ladder values of SMG (Carilli & Walter 2013). An rms loise level of 1 mJy at a velocity bin of 100 km/s would ensure detections at 30 sigma at the peak channel.

We apply for a bandwidth 1875 MHz, with spectral resolution 31.25 MHz (27.1 km/s), which is better than the final request resolution. However, the expected line may also be stronger, and we might be able to derive kinematic information from them. And other basebands could also potentially detect lines from other molecular transitions. So we would like to keep the resolution.
From previous studies (Henkel et al. 2010), we know the cloverleaf has a size less than 4" in diameter. Our uniformly requested resolution 2" will partly resolve the spatial distribution.

Line peak fluxes and FWHM estimated from Henkel et al. (2010), where they show a detection of 13CO 3-2. We expect that C18O can be as strong as 13CO. Because Cloverleaf is an extended target, so we will resolve it, but the final integrated spectrum will be used for the analyxis. We apply for similar r.m.s noise level 0.2 Jy/beam per 200km/s channel than the observation in Henkel et al. (2010), where they got a noise of 0.23 Jy/beam per 200km/s channel.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The stellar Initial Mass Function (IMF) plays a fundamental role in all galaxy formation, star formation and cosmological models. ALMA can powerfully probe the IMF types within heavily dust enshrouded star-forming galaxies, by measuring isotopic ratios of C and O (12C/13C, 16O/18O), which can be derived using the corresponding isotopologues. Here we propose to use ALMA to observe the ladders of isotopic CO lines (12CO, 13CO, and C18O) in four bright strongly lensed submm galaxies at redshifts ~2, at the peak of star formation in the Universe.. With non-LTE/Bayesian radiative transfer analysis and state-of-the-art galactic chemical evolution models (considering time-delay effects of the yields), the applied unique data and methods will serve as critical clues for the IMF variation across the cosmic time.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics and Astronomy, Edinburgh , University of
